title.text: UW-Stanford System Description for AESW 2016 Shared Task on Grammatical Error Detection

abstractContent.text: This is a report on the methods used and results obtained by the UW-Stanford team for the Automated Evaluation of Scientific Writing (AESW) Shared Task 2016 on grammatical error detection.

entities.text: Automated Evaluation of Scientific Writing (AESW) Shared Task 2016

abstractContent.text: This team developed a symbolic grammar-based system augmented with manually defined mal-rules to accommodate and identify instances of high-frequency grammatical errors.
System results were entered both for the probabilistic estimation track, where we ranked second, and for the Boolean decision track, where we ranked fourth.

introductionContent.text: Over the past several years, a series of shared tasks have been organized to foster research on the automatic detection of grammatical errors in compositions from a variety of genres.

entities.text: automatic detection of grammatical errors in compositions

introductionContent.text: In this year's task, the organizers invited participants to "analyze the linguistic characteristics of scientific writing to promote the development of automated writing evaluation tools that can assist authors in writing scientific papers.
The task is to predict whether a given sentence requires editing to ensure its 'fit' within the scientific writing genre."
This Automated Evaluation of Scientific Writing (AESW) Shared Task 2016 is described in more detail, along with descriptions of the seven teams and their system results, in.

entities.text: Automated Evaluation of Scientific Writing (AESW) Shared Task

introductionContent.text: This paper provides a description of the system adapted for this task by a team of collaborators from the University of Washington and from Stanford University, The system is based on a symbolic grammar augmented with a set of manually constructed mal-rules () designed to license and identify ungrammatical or stylistically deprecated sentence properties in running text.

We used an efficient parser to analyze the training and development sets repeatedly with successively refined versions of augmented grammar, producing for each sentence a derivation which recorded any use of mal-rules, thus triggering the "needs editing" flag relevant for the shared task.
In the end, we applied the bestperforming of these grammar versions to the test data in order to produce the results submitted for scoring.
